title: Salvador Dali's Essay "The Conquest of the Irrational"
author: PQ

highlights.text: We all know that the brilliant and sensational progress of the individual sciences, the glory and honor of the “space” and the era we live in, involves, on the one hand, the crisis and the overwhelming disrepute of “logical intuition,” and on the other hand, the respect for irrational factors and hierarchies as new positive and specifically productive values.
highlights.note: It’s still relevant in the sense that we’re even more dominated by specialized science/tech and by suspicion of simple “common sense,” while cultural life continues to be fascinated with irrational forces—unconscious drives, surreal imagery, conspiracy thinking, and so on.

highlights.text: and by the time Maxwell and Faraday were at work, this son was noticeably weighed down with an unequivocal persuasiveness and a personal force of gravity that left no doubt about the father of the child: Newton. Because of this downward pull and the force of gravity, pure intuition, after being booted out of the homes of all the particular sciences, has now turned into pure prostitution, for we see her offering her final charms and final turbulences in the brothel of the artistic and literary world.

epithet for the elusive taste of caviar and hiding the timid and gustatory germs of concrete irrationality, which, being merely the apotheosis and the paroxysm of the objective imponderable, constitutes the divisionist exactness and precision of the very caviar of imagination and will constitute, exclusively and philosophically, the terribly demoralizing and terribly complicated result of my experiences and inventions in painting.
highlights.note: Objective imponderable: Objective imponderables are philosophical entities or properties that are claimed to exist independently of human minds and yet cannot be fully measured, quantified, or directly observed. Debates about them focus on whether such features (for example, values, intrinsic qualities, or certain metaphysical truths) can be known objectively or are necessarily beyond empirical confirmation. Critics argue that invoking objective imponderables risks unverifiable metaphysics, while proponents maintain they are necessary to account for aspects of reality that resist reduction to measurable terms.

highlights.text: the world of concrete irrationality may be as objectively evident, consistent, durable, as persuasively, cognoscitively, and communicably thick as the exterior world of phenomenal reality.
